The distinctive “round round round” lines that continue after the main vocal line finishes were sung by Jackie Lomax, who had recently been signed to Apple Records.

At the  beginning of the track the fading sound of an airplane is heard. This is part of a segue from the previous track on the White Album, Back in the U.S.S.R.

The Travis style guitar fingerpicking pattern used throughout the song was taught to John Lennon by Donovan, who was also studying with the Maharishi Yogi at the time. This distinctive picking pattern, featuring quickly alternating bass notes, was used on a number of other songs on the White Album, including Julia and Happiness Is A Warm Gun.

Meditation is often used as an exercise in spiritually connecting to the whole of creation. The Beatles have explored this idea in songs such as “The Inner Light” and “Within You Without You”.

Lennon is saying that Prudence can experience this oneness with the world while also experiencing the world itself, if only she is willing to try.

Prudence is a real person, Mia Farrow’s younger sister, who was on a meditation retreat with the Beatles in India. She spent a lot of time indoors and had to be persuaded by John Lennon and George Harrison to come outside. Lennon later wrote this song about her.

She’d been locked in for three weeks and wouldn’t come out, trying to reach God quicker than anybody else. That was the competition in Maharishi’s camp: who was going to get cosmic first. What I didn’t know was I was already cosmic. [Laughs.]

– John Lennon

Prudence later confirmed she was more fanatical in her pursuit of enlightenment than those around her.

Being on that course was more important to me than anything in the world. I was very focused on getting in as much meditation as possible, so that I could gain enough experience to teach it myself. I knew that i must have stuck out because I would always rush straight back to my room after lectures and meals so that I could meditate. John, George and Paul would all want to sit around jamming and having a good time and I’d be flying into my room. They were all serious about what they were doing but they just weren’t as fanatical as me… At the end of the course, just as they were leaving, George mentioned that they had written a song about me but I didn’t hear it until it came out on the album. I was flattered. It was a beautiful thing to have done.

– Prudence Farrow

“The sun is up, the sky is blue” is probably a conscious echo of Buddy Holly’s “Raining In My Heart” which begins “The sun is out, the sky is blue” and also begins on a I chord with stepwise variations.

This was one of two songs (along with “Back In The USSR”) that Ringo Starr was not present for recording, after walking out on an argument in the studio.

McCartney stepped in and performed the drum parts in his place, including the extended military-esque drum fill that powers this section of the song.
